awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Permanent forearc strain partitioning in Northern Cascadia
awd_abstract_narration:
This work provides the first detailed characterization of the behavior of past earthquakes that have occurred on active, on-land, shallow faults in southern British Columbia, Canada. The research has important societal benefits that include providing key inputs needed for seismic hazard assessment in populated areas of Vancouver Island, British Columbia and northwestern Washington, USA. These types of data are necessary to help inform the development of public policy that can reduce the loss of life and property due to future earthquakes. Other important societal outcomes include contributions to STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) education and the development of a diverse globally competitive STEM workforce by providing support for the training  of graduate and undergraduate students. The project also supports the research of two female, early career scientists, and facilitates international collaborations between industry partners, policy makers, scientists and students. 

This project is evaluating the role of slab geometry and oblique convergence in the generation of forearc deformation in northern Cascadia by determining fault kinematics and the Holocene slip history of three prominent faults on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada. Using a combination of bedrock mapping and structural analysis, surficial mapping of offset Quaternary deposits, and exploratory paleoseismic trenches, the research is testing the hypothesis that newly identified active crustal faults contribute to active oroclinal bending in response to the component of relative plate motion parallel to the strike of the slab. This work provides the first documentation of Quaternary activity on a set of faults previously thought to be last active in the Eocene, and provides fundamental kinematic and slip history data necessary to test models of plate boundary strain partitioning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The earthquake history of four major faults within the subduction zone of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada were defined in detail using a combination of techniques, including paleoseismic trenches, interpretation of lidar topography data, geologic and geomorphic mapping, slickenline measurements, topographic surveys, and dating of key stratigraphic layers. The project showed, for the first time, that three of these faults have been active in the past ~12 thousand years, and these faults together make up a fault system that helps to accommodate active bending of the Olympic Orocline. The bending of the Olympic Orocline is a new hypothesis for how strain is built up and released over long time periods in this subduction zone, in a manner that is analogous to the Bolivian orocline of South America.


Three paleoseismic trenching expeditions were conducted across the Leech River, Elk Lake, and Beaufort Range Faults. These trenches and associated geologic and geomorphic mapping provided fault slip rates, recurrence intervals, and earthquake timing for each of these active fault systems. The project also allowed the first comprehensive and detailed evaluation of the slip history and style of fault slip on the San Juan Fault. The San Juan Fault was demonstrated to be a major left-lateral fault that helped accommodate a significant tectonic event ~50 million years ago--the collision of the island arc of Siletzia to North America. No direct evidence of recent (Quaternary) fault activity on the San Juan Fault was found.


This project is the first to place constraints on seismic hazard posed by faults that rupture the surface in the southern Vancouver Island region. The constraints on the earthquake timing, style, and recurrence interval from this study are direct inputs into seismic hazard models that inform building code policies in British Columbia and Canada more regionally. This work further underscores why lidar and paleoseismic trenching techniques are essential in identifying and characterizing these type of earthquake-producing structures. The award supported the research and training of one PhD student directly and two indirectly. Several undergraduate students participated in the research and gained valuable experience in the identification of active fault sources.
